Vanguard has a patented method of rebalancing their index mututal funds by doing the rebalancing in their mirroring ETFs and then importing the rebalance into the Mutual Funds The patent runs out fairly soon I think The reason why ETFs are more tax efficient than Mutual Funds is that all index funds need to rebalance their portfolios periodically to stay aligned to their indices This means they have to sell some positions and buy others If the positions they sell have gains then they will have to pay capital gains taxes which they will pass on to you if held in a taxable account ETFs can rebalance in a much more tax efficient way which causes considerably fewer taxable events than Mutual Funds can So ETFs are more tax efficient in taxable accounts Except for Vanguard who figured out how to do the rebalancing in their mirroring ETFs and import that into the Mutual Funds in a tax efficient way and then were clever enough to patent it

Selfemployment taxes are separate from your federal tax When you have a job as a regular employee in addition to tax you also pay half of whats often referred to as payroll taxes or FICA taxes for Social Security and for Medicare Your employer pays the other half Since these are flat rates out of your paycheck and dont really show up anywhere on your federal tax return unless there was an error in the withholding When you are selfemployed you have to pay both the employer and employee halves of those taxes for a total of on of your net profits and thats referred to as selfemployment taxes This gets calculated on Schedule SE which is filed along with your tax return Its an entirely separate parallel set of taxes you pay so its not affected by things like the standard deduction of the tax Since the US tax system is pay as you earn and taxes arent withheld from earnings you receive as an independent contractor youre supposed to make quarterly estimated tax payments Filing at the end of the year is just settling up any minor differences

Recharacterization applies to contributions When you recharacterize a contribution its basically saying oops I meant for that to be this other type of contribution You can only recharacterize contributions for a given tax year until the filing deadline for that tax year including extensions You can recharacterize in either direction ie a Roth contribution traditional or a traditional contribution Roth When you recharacterize any earnings attributable to that contribution go along for the ride Conversion is when you transfer money from a traditional retirement account to a Roth account and this is not limited to any specific tax year In other words you could convert the entire balance of your traditional IRA if you wanted to even if it contains money you contributed several years ago When you convert from a traditional IRA to a Roth IRA you pay taxes on whatever portion of the conversion consists of pretax contributions and earnings You used to be able to recharacterize a conversion ie undo the conversion but this was eliminated by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of Recharacterization of contributions is still allowed

gt Can I rollover my pretax IRA contributions to my k leaving only my after tax contributions remaining in my traditional IRA Yes though doing it the other way around might be easier Basically just roll over however much to leave your IRA with the aftertax basis indicated by your last filed Everything else is considered pretax even gains from aftertax contributions So say you have k in your IRA and your last basis is k line or whatever Then you would roll over k to your k leaving k to convert to Roth without incurring any tax Alternatively and probably better just convert the roth first since you know the exact basis and make sure to rollover the rest to a k before Dec All that matters is that you clear out your pretax by Dec the order doesnt matter beyond that Also if you contribute more during the year you do the conversion that can of course be converted to Roth too just remember to file again

If you have a bunch of small public loans are they separate Do you pay them separately or do you make one consolidated payment If they are separate you can pay off the smallest balance ones Then there wont be minimum payments for those The cash that would be allocated to paying those can be used to pay off other small debts When all the small debts are paid you can use all that extra monthly cash to pay towards the big one This is generally referred to as the Snowball Method of debt payoff It frees up cash flow the fastest and to a lot of people cash flow is more important than saving on interest For example if you pay off k of those k public loans maybe you pay off all but one k loan out of the bunch You go from paying month towards them to paying month Or whatever it ends up being That difference of continues to be applied toward that last k public loan But if some financial hardship happens you can stop paying that toward the loan and put it somewhere else each month On the other hand if you chunk the whole k toward the private loan cash flow doesnt change The loan balance goes down but you still owe the same amount every month until it is paid off If that same financial hardship happens you have no flexibility to adjust payments

does not have an IRA Individual Retirement Account may have a k A nonprofit may have a b There are other types retirement plans but these are not referred to as an IRA An IRA is ty something you the individual open to save for retirement Assuming you are referring to k plan Eligibility date There is usually a waiting period outlined in the plan documents before you can begin participating in a k Once eligible you can contribute whatever percent of your salary you choose pretax or posttax the later being known as a Roth k Applicable limits For one can contribute up to if below age If above age you can add an additional totaling in catch up contributions Investment funds most employers choose an Fidelity Vanguard Schwab to administer their plan The menu of fund choices will be decided ty by or employer based on whats available from that or with guidance from that You then choose from the menu of investment options to create your desired portfolio Rollovers if you have money in an IRA or other k b outside of this plan all these are known as qualified retirement vehicles you can roll over or transfer those funds into your new k Safe Harbor plan A safe harbor plan is set up by when it wants to avoid the nondiscrimination test In short agrees to give each employee a certain match so if there is a difference in the amount various employees eg those that are highly paid versus those that are not are contributing does not get in trouble with the IRS This but basically the IRS says ALL employees should be able to take advantage of these retirement vehicles not just the executives of using them to avoid taxes while us plebs slog away unable to contribute due to low wages Profit Share takes excess revenue profit each year and makes it available as a bonus contribution to your k above and beyond your contributions and the match up to total I hope that helps

Credit scores have nothing to do with how likely you are personally to pay back debt Instead theyre a statistical measure of abilitylikeliness to pay back debt So statistically people that paid back a loan years ago are probably equally as likely to pay back new debt on time as someone that didnt have a loan years ago Its not about getting knocked for not having an active nonmortgage loan its that statistically people that are currently keeping up with a payment plan and always paying on time are more likely to keep making ontime payments to new debt than those who arent currently paying back debt The whole system is in place as a statistical way to determine whos likely to pay back debt on time If you want methods that arent just based on statistics you can go through other means such as peertopeer lending but Id guess that rates are generally going to be cheaper by going through institutions that use your credit score if your credit score is at least decent

Few things First more means more taxes Because of marginal rates their next two ks are taxed more than the k both of you make So even though their gross is x yours theyre not actually living on x more because theyre stuck between a car payment or two and massive cell phone cable bills or are barely managing to cover the cost of a desired vacation They could have made less expensive choices but they decided instead to try to make the effort to live that lifestyle Or maybe they were making more money when they made the choices and lost a job and got rehired at a lower rate or were expecting more better raises over time than they wound up getting and ignore the instability sales and real estate Because of laws relating to debt repayment they cant not make those payments and so they struggle to Youre likely to get approved for an amount but that shouldnt be considered what you can afford Also your saved wont be your total down payment because you will have closing costs Closing costs consist of normal house buying fees plus taxes and insurance money needed to begin your escrow account Sometimes a seller will chip in some of these costs but usually only if theyre desperate to unload the house quickly Youll need a minimum of down payment plus the closing costs in order to close Youll have to figure out with the help of a realtor or lending firm what the estimated closing costs will be Your mortgage payment will also rise based on your credit score because that determines which rate you will be eligible to receive Your rate determines how much interest you pay In most cases you pay more interest each month than principal the amount that is actually applied toward the loan for the first of the mortgage term You can follow along using an amortization schedule which is provided to you at closing but can also be made in a program like Excel Its probably best for your financial wellness to pay off your debt then continue to save money for a full down payment closing costs It is also wise to have at least months worth of mortgageutility payments left over in a savings account

If you didnt get a new phone or spent less on one than you could put that money towards your student loan debt So you are effectively borrowing money to buy an upgraded phone You are choosing a want over a need here It doesnt mean that it wont work out or that it is some life altering amount of money But at the end of the day you are choosing to prioritize an expensive phone upgrade over paying down your debts From a purely financial and numbers standpoint I would that you buy something less expensive and only after it necessary to upgrade From a life perspective I dont have a problem with it as long as you dont make this sort of decision a habit in all aspects of life If you are generally frugal and thoughtful about what you purchase then it is probably fine to splurge a bit If not then this is a bad habit to get into It is easy to justify eating out a vacation a newer car a top of the line phone etc in the microcosm of that single purchase However that behavior in a macrocosm is what leads people into pretty bad financial situations You know you and you know your situation and behavior better than anyone here so you will have to make a value judgement as to whether or not this particular phone is worth splurging on As an aside you sound pretty responsible and thoughtful I do wonder if you asked the question because you knew it was not the most responsible thing to do This advice is as much for the average person that may read it later as it is for you I dont really want someone else along and just see a person in debt get told it is OK to get a brand new phone The blanket answer is no If all of your other stuff is sorted out then I wont argue it but paying off debt is financially more important than having a nicernewer phone Cheers and Good Luck

I opened up an investment account and instead of making payment to the card and I just let the balance build Here is my experience Its not as effective if your card gives other benefit than just the APR For example if your card also give cash back and APR if you take advantage of the APR then you cant really take the cashback since you will quickly fill the card limit and then end up not being able to churn money through the card build balance pay off balance repeat to get that cash back The return isnt that good I assume your strat is instead of paying the card you just invest the cash The rate of return of even a k limit for a full year is probably at in stock market or But you only get that if you have an expense that would have cost you k anyway and you put that on the card to defer the expense In effect you have an opportunity gains of So this is like a saving account starting at k and gain for the year However if you dont have a big purchase and slowly building this k via normal expense your opportunity gain diminish The gains would be similar to having a saving account starting from zero about half the gain So long story short Zero APR card is only effective if you have a huge up and would like to defer the expense and have an opportunity gain If you go with a zero APR card then go for a card that a has the longest period months and or b very high limit so you can borrow as long as you can as much as you can Ignore other features since you cannot take advantage of anyway If you dont have a big expense I wouldnt bother with it Good luck

Real estate in portfolio can be WITHOUT a house This is important When you look at houses they call it an investment but it is not the same as investing in the stock market A house alone especially a primary residence is objectively a significantly disadvantaged investment as an asset class for several reasons A house is the only asset class where the acquisition and liquidation costs ie closing costs are significant Buying and selling stock costs you buying a house costs you of asset value A house cost to own is significant ie maintenance Maintenance of of the total value not equity is like buying stock with management fee Just these two alone makes it inferior as an investment when better alternatives exists such as REIT where neither disadvantages mentioned above exists This is why we never buy an empty house and leave it vacant except for the Chinese where there are literally no other alternative so they buy a house and leave it vacant So if you purely wants to diversify do something else Now lets turn the questions a bit differently Can a house be a good investment There are two cases when they are The asset is revenue generating with a positive rate of return ie rental property or a property that appreciate via local market or forced appreciation via flipping It serves a purpose to full fill a need for your life where alternatives to fullfill this need is more expensive we are talking about opportunity costs here In this sense it would be the same as is this a good investment the answer in this case depends on the person and its role in that persons life For case I dont expect that would be you unless you are planning to be a landlord or house flipping so thats out What you are left with is a big bet that your local rental markets returns well Thats a bet you can make But its risk profile is so different you cant really predict For case the mindset is different If you are just watching youtube then a mac is a terrible investment a small tablet might serve you better But if you are a professional photographer needing some pretty accurate color on for work then hell yea thats the best investment in your arsenal See hows there a bit of a difference here There is already a need for the asset as a utility and this utility makes the asset a good investment In other words if you need a house then a house can be a good to the other alternative of living you always gotta live somewhere But if you dont need a house a house is not going to be a good investment for you since you have no utility for the house and also a terrible asset class So buy a house when you need a house like buying when you need But dont buy to diversify thats like saying buy a and hold it for the value Its not really an asset class that to stock and bonds and therefore should not be considered as a mean to diversify portfolio There are other perspective on using real estate to get access to tax deductions generate revenue and access to leverage to get appreciation However all of those after you have decided that you indeed need and or want a house If you dont need or want one those advantages cannot offset the disadvantages listed at least at the current climate where alternative exists

As you may already know a reverse mortgage is different that a standard mortgage In lieu of making monthly payments on the debt the lender either issues your parents a monthly stipend amount or it would appear in this case that they make have taken a lump sum payment when they opened the loan Either way the mortgage balance continues to accumulate interest which the lender earns using equity in the home At the time your last parent passes on or when they both move out of the property the note fully due and payable The lender will do a calculation at that time of the amount that has been disbursed and the current value of the property It is possible that the total balance due may exceed the current value of the home The reverse mortgage protects the estate in that if there is a deficiency balance it cannot be passed on to the heir The lender should offer the estate the option to pay the deficiency balance to retain the property or to assign the property to the lender at which time the loan would be considered paid If there is positive equity in the home the lender should offer the estate the option to refinance the amount owed into a forward mortgage to sell the property and payoff the lien through the sale or to assign the property to the lender Regardless of which scenario applies you should know that the property does not automatically transfer to the lender which is misconception about reverse mortgages Your parents will or estate planning document will designate who inherits the property and the executor or the person that receives the direct inheritance will be able to work with the lender to identify the best path forward which should offer you options to ultimately transfer ownership of the property to your brother

Hi Lenders will consider both your current and historical earnings when assisting you in qualifying for a new home loan Different mortgage products have different guidelines but you are correct that almost all products will universally look at the most recent two years of historical earnings as an indicator of the amount and stability of your future earnings However your specific situation is a bit unique Generally a lender will be more willing to calculate your qualifying based on your current earnings even if it has substantially increased recently if your new higher earnings are likely to continue at that level One example would be a physician that has their residency and has now joined a practice at a much higher salary The same principal could be applied to your situation as you progress from an apprentice to a journeyman Your status as a journeyman and your on the job training as an apprentice would make it generally acceptable that you will earn at a higher rate going forward in your career which would allow lenders to consider your current higher salary even though your historical for the past two years has been lower The one item that will be crucial is the nature of your employment Most journeyman and unionbased tradesman in general will experience periodic gaps in employment as you are assigned to specific jobs through your union affiliation When you apply for a mortgage the lender will consider your current position and likelihood that that salary will reasonably continue for at least three years into the future At the time of application if you have accepted employment for a project that may only last six months before you move on to a to perform similar services then the lender would likely not consider your new higher as reasonably likely to continue and would average your current earnings with your prior years earnings However if you accepted an openended assignment for example with a large developer that was constructing multiple The answer to your question largely depends on your current interest rate and how long you have been making payments on your current loan There are several things to consider The percentage of your monthly mortgage payment that is applied to interest vs principal is by design much greater at the beginning of your loan term than it is at the end of your loan term Mortgage interest is a simple interest calculation and therefore the more money you owe the greater the amount of interest you owe As you continue to make payments and decrease your principal balance the interest portion less and the amount applied to principal greater Therefore applying your lump sum to a recast may be more advantageous if you are in the first few years of repayment on the loan as the recast will lower your principal balance and therefore more of each subsequent payment will go towards your principal balance However a recast will not decrease the total number of payments required on the mortgage it will only change your minimum monthly payment If you have been paying on your current mortgage for ten or more years you will probably be better served to apply your lump sum as a single principal reduction without the recast feature This will leave your payment amount the same but will give the same benefit of the recast in that your principal balance will be smaller and therefore the amount of interest applied from each monthly payment will be decreased It appears that your current loan payment includes a monthly amount for Private Mortgage Insurance PMI Applying a lump sum payment will not automatically cancel the PMI Your rights as a consumer related to Private Mortgage Insurance are outlined in the Homeowners Protection Act of You may request cancellation of the Mortgage Insurance Policy but you must do so with a written request to your servicer OR the lender is required to AUTOMATICALLY cancel the policy with no action required from you when the principal balance of the mortgage is first SCHEDULED to reach of the original value of the secured properly The trick to the automated cancellation is that the SCHEDULED date is based solely on the initial amortization schedule for fixed rate loans This means that even if you make a large lump sum principal reduction which would reduce your balance to or less of the value of the home when you purchased the lender is not required to use that reduction to issue an automatic termination The original amortization schedule is based on the amount you originally borrowed minus your regularly scheduled payments Therefore you would likely need to request the termination of the policy after you made your principal reduction At that time the servicing lender has the right to review you request and consider things such as your payment history and the current market value of your home which may require you to pay for a new appraisal A third option that you did not mention may be refinancing The benefit of refinancing will be entirely dependent on the interest rate you currently have on the loan however it might be beneficial to look at the cost involved with a refinance that would lower or keep your remaining term the same If there is a significant opportunity to lower your current interest rate through refinancing then this may be the best option as neither a recast nor a principal reduction will lower the interest rate on your current loan A refinance has the added benefit that your current market value and loan amount will be used to determine equity and may cancel the need for your Mortgage Insurance policy as well Unfortunately there is no easy answer to your question however there are several online free amortization calculators that you can find to plug in your loan specifics and determine overall total costs for the remaining term of your loan

Assuming this is a conventional loan When you first get your mortgage you pay PMI if your down payment is less than of the purchase price In your example of the Sellers being generous and selling for less than market value it doesnt matter because if they sell to you for k instead of k the bank then sees the value as k When PMI is dropped as you make payments is a little weird its based on your amortization schedule As soon as you are scheduled to have paid your loan down to oddly of the original purchase price not the PMI goes away Federal law built in a little bit of buffer However if you make extra payments or if you believe the home has risen enough in value that you now owe less than of what it is actually worth you can ask the bank to do a new appraisal of the home which usually costs If you do in fact owe less than of the actual appraised value over equity position you can get the PMI removed manually How soon you are able to do this after purchase may depend on the bank For FHA loans the rules are entirely different As long as your down payment is at least of the purchase price you can get the mortgage insurance removed after years You still have mortgage insurance if you put down And if you put down less than youre stuck with it until the loan is paid off

Well as I said rInvesting is a for questions and research on that front As for ETFs some track different industries and have different portfolios For example VOO is Vanguards SampP index fund US based while VT is Vanguards total world stock ETF Some ETFs get even more specific following industries like natural gas tech or utilities For more specific guidance look at some target retirement date funds many brokerages have them for dates close to when youd like to retire You can either mirror these investments or actually invest into these funds Many of them have low expense ratios and are managed to have appropriate levels of risk depending on your timeline Heres an article from that goes more into the specifics As for taxes that all depends Some ETFs pay dividends which are taxed These dividends will in the form of checks or will be credited to your brokerage account some brokerages even allow you to reinvest dividends automatically However for the actual ETF shares you dont pay any taxes until you sell the shares like a stock If you sell the shares after owning them for less than a year your gains are taxed at a high rate short term capital gains however if you hold on to them for a while your gains are taxed at a much lower rate long term capital gains To be clear you pay taxes on the GAINS not the overall value of the stock For example If you buy a share of an ETF at then sell it off later for the gain of is taxed not the overall value of the share at Of course most brokerages will automatically prepare you a around tax time with all of your sales and dividends accounted for so you shouldnt have to worry about the nittygritty

Directly from the IRS Insolvent estate Generally if a decedents estate is insufficient to pay all the decedents debts the debts due to the United States must be paid first Both the decedents federal tax liabilities at the time of death and the estates tax liability are debts due to the United States The personal representative of an insolvent estate is personally responsible for any tax liability of the decedent or of the estate if he or she had notice of such tax obligations or failed to exercise due care in determining if such obligations existed before distribution of the estates assets and before being discharged from duties The extent of such personal responsibility is the amount of any other payments made before paying the debts due to the United States except where such other debt paid has priority over the debts due to the United States tax liabilities need not be formally assessed for the personal representative to be liable if he or she was aware or should have been aware of their existence

One way to get started in real estate is to buy a house perhaps a double or duplex where you rent out one side and live in the other If you look around you may find a house that has Motherinlaw quarters or even a smaller house on the same lot These are not usually attractive to most regular home buyers so can be bought for less than you may think then rent out the space to help pay for the mortgage Renting a bedroom in your personal space can be a challenge and a friend can work but also may be the best way to destroy that friendship You may be reluctant to throw them out if they dont pay rent or dont follow the rules more than paying the mortgage you have to protect the investment you made buying the house Being a landlord can be tough and you will want to have a signed lease that spells out what the tenant friend or not is to do and what the consequences are Lease templates are widely available online that you can customize For someone you dont know a background check can also be ordered online for a modest fee do this to be sure you know who you are dealing with Looking ahead when all is said and done and provided you manage this well you can end up with a good part of the mortgage if not all being paid by the renter and can save up to buy your next and nicer home and may even keep the house to rent out for Over time as the rental house gets paid down and appreciates in value you may find you can sell it for a nice chunk of cash Ive successfully done this and there are others on here who likely have as well so dont hesitate to reach out with any questions If this is your first house it can be a bit scary but once youve bought and sold or properties you will be with the process Best of luck

I felt this way for a long time and often still go through periods of feeling like what Im doing isnt enough Financial independence and security are massively important to me and occasionally meeting my own expectations can feel pretty overwhelming Im so not all that much older than you So heres how Ive personally handled it Work out a monthly budget for the things you absolutely have to pay for rent utilities student loans train fare etc Consciously think about extraneous purchases Do you really need a third pair of sneakers or a vehicle upgrade or new towels Keep frivolous spending to a minimum but dont be so frugal you dont enjoy your life I keep a list of items I want and periodically review it If an item is on the list for a few months I have the money and I still want it then I buy it This habit has helped me cut back on impulse purchases significantly Set up automatic transfers to a savings account and a retirement account from each paycheck Its easier not to spend it if you never even see it in your main account Set small goals intermediate goals and long terms goals For me this was paying off my car loan having months of emergency funding in a savings account and buying a home Once you reach them set new goals Checking goals off a list helps me see the progress and destress about everything a bit Learn about investing Knowledge is power Read books ask friends in finance ask family about their financial habits Dont avoid investing because it makes you nervous but also dont go into it blindly Review your budget annually or anytime theres a big change moving raise loan paid off etc ampxB Comparisons can be dangerous but I feel pretty confident saying youre doing better than many people your age The number of people I know who are in their s and even s who dont save dont plan and dont seem to care at all is astounding Financial planning and real adulthood can hit you like a ton of bricks in your early s Youll adjust to it
